Award.AwardTitle: Upgrade of Computing Facilities to support Geodynamics and Tectonics Research at UC Davis
Award.AbstractNarration: This award will fund the acquisition of compute nodes to add to one of UC Davis' community clusters in order to support both currently funded and future NSF research projects. With this funding, 8 nodes (384 cores) with 128 TB of storage will be added to the community cluster providing computing resources needed to carry out numerical simulations related to several different research projects. The compute nodes will support projects for both current and future graduate and undergraduate students and postdocs conducting research within the Department of Earth and Planetary Sciences. Having direct access to these resources helps students to learn about high performance computing. <br/><br/>Numerical simulations are a powerful method for testing hypothesis about how various aspects of subduction occur, including the interplay between dynamics, material properties and mineralogy. This funding will provide the infrastructure needed to conduct models on: 1) currently funded NSF projects including the development of lattice-preferred orientation in subduction zones and its connection to seismic anisotropy and the coupling between, slab and mantle deformation and surface deformation in the present-day Cascadia subduction zone, 2) other current projects on the role of the plate boundary shear zone in controlling trench retreat, and modeling thermal shear instabilities within the deep slab, and 3) planned research projects, including the link between strain-rate variation in subducted lithosphere and the distribution and triggering mechanism for deep earthquakes, the mechanism by which fluids enter the oceanic crust in the bending region of the outer rise, and the interaction between rising mantle plumes and subducting slabs.<br/><br/>This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The award funded the purchase of 8 high performance compute nodes, each with 128 cores and 64 GB of RAM, for a total of 1024 cores and 512 GB of RAM.  These computing resources are used to support a variety of research into the process of subduction and its implications. Subduction is the process by which one tectonic plate converges with, and sinks beneath, another tectonic plate. This research is conducted by undergraduate and graduates students and post-doctoral scholars as hands-on training towards their various college degree goals. Since the nodes came on line in late 2021, 1 postdoc, 3 graduate students, and 2 undergraduate students have used these resources for their research. The computing resources have supported research related to:

- the deformation around the sinking Juan de Fuca  tectonic plate in Oregon and Washington, where stresses caused by this sinking build up over time and are released in large earthquakes. 

- the effect of nearby diverging plates on the melting that occurs in the mantle above a sinking tectonic plate. This melting is the source for magma erupted in volcanoes at the earth's surface. 

- the causes of earthquakes deep (400-700 km) in the sinking plate.

- the effect of various rock properties and geometrical effects on the modes of sinking of the plate into the mantle

- the conditions under which sediments can be carried deep into the mantle by a sinking tectonic plate. 

This research has already been reported on in one Masters thesis, one PhD thesis and various presentations to the scientific community. There are currently 9 research journal article in preparation from this research started just 2 years ago.  

The compute nodes will continue to support the research of students in my research group throughout the lifetime of the compute nodes (about 5-6 years). I expect to continue to have about 1 post-doctoral fellow, 2-3 graduate students and several undergraduates use the resource for their research each year.
